How can I modify my current script that writes to a file to overwrite the file if it already exists, instead of appending text to it? Here is my current script:
```bash
echo "text" >> 'Users/Name/Desktop/TheAccount.txt'
```
I want it to create the file if it doesn't exist, but overwrite it if it already exists.

To modify your script so that it overwrites the file if it already exists, you should use a single `>` instead of `>>`. The `>` operator will create the file if it doesn't exist and overwrite it if it does. Here's how you can modify your script:

```bash
echo "text" > 'Users/Name/Desktop/TheAccount.txt'
```

This change will ensure that each time you run the script, the file `TheAccount.txt` will be overwritten with the new content `"text"`.
